metadata.title: Effect of differentially heated tubes on natural convection heat transfer in a space between two adiabatic horizontal concentric cylinders using nano-fluid

Effect of differentially heated tubes on natural convection heat transfer in a space between two adiabatic horizontal concentric cylinders using nano-fluid
Yulin Ma a , Mojtaba Jamiatia b , Alireza Aghaei c , Mohammad Sepehrirad d , Amin Dezfulizadeh d , Masoud Afrand e , f , ∗
a Suzhou Automotive Research Institute, Tsinghua University, Suzhou 215134, PR China b Department of Physics, Naragh Branch, Islamic Azad University, Naragh, Iran c Young Researchers and Elite Club, Arak Branch, Islamic Azad University, Arak, Iran d Department of Mechanical Engineering, Arak Branch, Islamic Azad University, Arak, Iran e Laboratory of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials, Advanced Institute of Materials Science, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam f Faculty of Applied Sciences, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
a r t i c l e i n f o
Keywords: Heat transfer Free convection Laminar regime Coaxial cylinders Nano-fluid
a b s t r a c t
In the present numerical study, the free convective flow between several differentially hot and cold tubes enclosed in a space between two horizontal adiabatic coaxial cylinders which filled with three different kinds of nano-fluids is investigated. The effects of influential aspects including; location of heat source/sink, number of tubes, Rayleigh number ( Ra ), volume concentration ( 𝜙) and type of the nanoadditives on the isotherms, streamline, stream function and average Nusselt number ( 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 ) are explored. The governing equations are solved numerically employing control-volume based finite volume technique. For pressure-velocity coupling, the Semi-Implicit Method is utilized. According to the obtained results, usage of nano-fluid leads to the considerable enhancement of heat transfer in the studied cavity. For all the examined configurations with two cylinders, the configuration 30° has the most 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 values which is followed by configurations 60° or 0°, 90°, 120°, 150° and 180°, respectively. It is clearly seen that for all the assessed configurations with three cylinders, the highest to lowest 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 respectively belongs to the Case 2C, Case 2A and Case 2B. Moreover, for all the investigated configurations with four cylinders, the highest and lowest 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 respectively occurs at Case 3B and Case 3A.

. Introduction
Buoyancy-induced convection phenomenon in enclosures filled with uid plays an important role in some of industry and engineering appliation such as nuclear reactor design, electronics cooling, heat exchangrs and thermal energy storage systems [1–4] . Also in recent decades, he convection heat transfer between horizontal cylinders is taken into onsideration more than ever.
Designers are often reluctant to utilize mechanical equipment to crete fluid flow, especially when a small power consumption, a negligible perating noise, and a high reliability of the system, are main concerns. owever, the inherently poor energy efficiency of natural and mixed onvection, in comparison with equivalent or similar forced convection ases, represents a substantial restriction to heat transfer. As well the cceptance of the conventional techniques which are used to enhance he heat transfer according to the usage of turbulators is a imaginable

Kumar [8] investigated free convective flow in a horizonal annuli geometry where the inner cylinder is under a constant heat ux (hot wall) and the outer cylinder has a constant temperature (cold all). Ho et al. [9] studied numerically the natural/mixed convection eat transfer in two horizontal cylindrical annuli (coaxial and eccenric). 11] studied numerically 2D and 3D turbulent free convective flow in orizontal annulus. The finite volume method was used for their nuerical modeling of the turbulent fluid flow. They realized that for sufciently long annulus, it is possible to simulate approximately the free onvective flow in horizontal annulus by a 2D model. Also they realized hat usage of radial fins on inner cylinder has a significant influence n heat transfer in annulus. Existence of such fins makes the flow and eat transfer characteristics substantially different from those of annuus without fins. This flow geometry has been investigated for laminar ow case by Chai and Patankar [12] , Sheikhzadeh et al. [13] and Arbaan and Salimpour [14] . Chai and Patankar [12] investigated the fluid ow and heat transfer characteristics for a horizontal annulus equipped ith six radial fins. They found that the internal fins orientation has not ny significant influence on the 𝑁𝑢 . It is while the fluid flow, tempera-

ure field and heat transfer rate are sharply affected by fins properties. heikhzadeh et al. [13] studied numerically the nano-fluid flow and heat ransfer characteristics for two different cases with two and four fins. hey realized that the 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 rises by growing the Ra and 𝜙. Also they ound that the fins length and the number of fins have an important inuence on 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 and the 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 reduces with growing of length and number f fins. Arbaban and Salimpour [14] studied numerically the hydrotheral aspects of nano-fluid flowing inside a coaxial annuls with internally nned inner cylinder and using three different nano-fluids. They realzed that the 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 intensifies by boosting of 𝜙. Also they observed that he temperature gradient and absolute value of stream function reduces n case of using nano-fluid instead of base fluid. Rahnama and Farhadi 15] studied numerically the free convective flow of turbulent fluid flow egime between two horizontal coaxial cylinders equipped with radial ns. They realized that at the same Ra the heat transfer rate reduces by oosting of fins number.
In a numerical assessment, Gap et al. [16] examined the free conective flow in a square cavity with circular cylinders. It was reported hat growing the Ra causes an intensification in the heat transfer rate. ark et al. [17] studied numerically laminar free convective flow in an nclined square cavity with inner circular cylinder. They realized that he averaged Nusselt number reduces along the top and left walls by oosting of cavity tilted angel. It is while the averaged Nusselt number nhances along the bottom and right wall by boosting of cavity tilted ngel. Wang et al. [18] and Dai et al. [19] in similar studies investigated aminar free convective flow in a 2D horizontal square cavity with two ylinders having different temperatures. It was found that the 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 is a unction of tube arrangement. Khanafer et al. [20] studied numerically ixed convection heat transfer in a lid driven enclosure with inner cirular cylinder. They found that the 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 enhances with intensify of cyliner radius for all the studied Richardson numbers. Öztop et al. [21] and minossadati et al. [22] studied mixed convection heat transfer probem in a two-sided lid-driven enclosure. At low Richardson numbers, the 𝑢 𝑖 changed sharply with moving walls direction changing. Park et al. 23] investigated numerically free convective heat transfer in a square nclosure with 4 inner circular cylinders. It was reported that the variaion in isotherm and streamline patterns varies drastically with distance etween enclosure walls and hot cylinders. Al-Zamily et al. [24] studed numerically the nano-fluid flow and magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) ree convective flow in a semi-circular cavity. They observed that the eat transfer rate enhances by boosting of the Ra and the 𝜙. Hedayti et al. [25,26] conducted simulations to assess the mixed convection ow of nano-fluid through a vertical microchannel. The outcomes reealed that replacing the heat sources with smaller ones results in the nhancement of heat transfer. In a numerical assessment, Kefayati [27– 1] analyzed the mixed convection flow of nano-fluid in a differentially eated cavity and reported the Nusselt number enhancement by growng the 𝜙. Kalteh et al. [32] investigated numerically different nanoaditive diameter effects on mixed convection heat transfer inside a lid riven square enclosure. They found that at all Richardson numbers the eat transfer rate reduces by growing the nanoadditives diameter. Malandi et al. [33–36] studied numerically nano-fluid flow and natural and ixed convection heat transfer inside two different cavities (vertical and orizontal) under magnetic field effects. They found that in attendance f a magnetic field, the decline of heat transfer diminishes especially at igh nanoadditives diameters. Moradi et al. [37] investigated numerially fluid flow and free convective flow of Newtonian nano-fluids in an solated cylindrical cavity. They realized that the heat transfer rate enances with intensify of the enclosure aspect ratio. Selimefendigil et al. 38,39] investigated numerically nano-fluid flow and the MHD mixed onvection heat transfer in a lid-driven cavity equipped with a rotatng circular cylinder. In the attendance of a magnetic field, the velocity eld and convection heat transfer within the cavity were underdevelped. Also, it was reported that the heat transfer rate intensifies with rowing the 𝜙. Sheikholeslami et al. Sheremet and Pop [56] investigated numerically free convection in porous horizontal cylindrical annulus with a nano-fluid using Buoniorno’s model. In another study Sheremet and Pop [57] analyzed nuerically free convection in a horizontal cylindrical annulus filled with porous medium saturated by a nano-fluid using Tiwari and Das’nanouid model. Bondareva et al. [58] studied heatline visualization of free onvection in a thick walled open cavity filled with a nano-fluid. Also, ondareva et al. [59] investigated entropy generation due to free conection of a nano-fluid in a partially open triangular cavity.
The literature review elucidates that although the free convective ow in a space between two horizontal adiabatic coaxial cylinders hich filled with nano-fluids has been assessed, but, to the best of au-
hor’s knowledge there is not any study which investigates the free conective flow between several differentially hot and cold tubes enclosed n a space between two horizontal adiabatic coaxial cylinders which lled with nano-fluid. The main aim of the present work is to investiate numerically the free convective flow between several differentially ot and cold tubes enclosed in a space between two horizontal adiaatic coaxial cylinders which filled with three different kinds of nanouids. The impacts of influential aspects including; location of the heat ource/sink, number of tubes, Ra , 𝜙 and nano-fluid type on the pattern f isotherms, streamlines, stream function and 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 are explored.
. Problem definition
The free convective flow between several differentially heated tubes nclosed in a space between two horizontal adiabatic coaxial cylinders s investigated in the present work. Fig. 1 indicates a schematic diagram f differentially heated annulus that the present work has been validated y it.
Fig. 2 shows the geometries used in the present study. A polar cordinate system is adopted in such a way that the radial coordinate r s measured from the center and the angular coordinate 𝜃 is measured ounter-clockwise from the downward vertical symmetric line, along hich direction gravity acts. The hot and cold tubes are kept at constant emperatures and they are T h = 305 K, and T c = 295 K, respectively. It s while the cylinders surfaces are insulated. The reference temperature s T ref = ( T h + T c )/2 and it has been chosen as the average value of hot nd cold tubes. The following assumptions are predicted:
• The nano-fluid is incompressible and the flow regime is laminar. • The nano-fluid is treated as single-phase fluid.
• The base fluids and nanoadditive are in thermal equilibrium and no slip condition takes place between them. • The thermophysical properties of the nano-fluid are considered to be constant with the exception of density which differs according to the Boussinesq approximation.

The governing equations given in Eqs. (19)–(22) subjected to the forementioned boundary conditions given by Eq. (26) are solved umerically using control-volume based finite volume method. The iffusion term in the governing equations is estimated by a second-order entral difference scheme while a second-order upwind differencing cheme is engaged to discretize the convective terms. The Semi-Implicit ethod for Pressure Linked Equation-Consistent (SIMPLE ‒C) algorithm escribed by Van Doormaal and Raithby [69] is adopted to couple he velocity field and pressure in the momentum equations. The onvergence criterion for all the parameters was considered equal o 10 − 7 .
. Code validation and mesh independence test
Due the lack of experimental data for free convection in an annuus, the numerical procedure is validated by the experimental results of uehn and Goldstein [5] for Ra L = 2.09 • 10 5 , Pr = 5.45, ΔT = 0.371K, avg = 303.18K and L /2 ri = 0.8 providing T i > T o (see Fig. 1 ). The comarisons for six temperature profiles at six different angles, (angle meaured from the lower symmetry plane), are indicated in Fig. 3 . Numercal test related to the dependence of the results on the mesh spacing ave been performed methodically. A grid testing is undertaken for two ifferentially heated tubes at horizontal position ( 𝜃 = 90°) enclosed in a pace between two horizontal adiabatic coaxial cylinders filled with waer that the value of 𝑁𝑢 𝑡𝑜𝑡 is reported for temperature difference of tubes T = T h − T c = 10K, r o / r i = 2.5, R tubes / r i = 0.2 and H / L = 0.5. Seven nonniform nodes are engaged for the numerical procedure and the results re indicated in Table 2 . It is obvious that from the results, the grid with 0,319 nodes is fine to certify a grid independent solution adequately. ig. 3 b shows demonstration of grid mesh layout.

. Conclusions
In this work, the free convective flow between several differentially ot and cold tubes enclosed in a space between two horizontal adiabatic oaxial cylinders which filled with three different kinds of nano-fluids as investigated numerically. The control-volume based finite volume pproach was utilized to perform the required simulations. According o the obtained results, usage of nano-fluid has a noticeable impact on he hydrothermal aspects of the studied cavity. For all cases and volume ractions of configurations with two cylinders the configuration 30° has he most 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 values which is followed by configurations 60° or 0°, 90°, 20°, 150° and 180°, respectively. It is clearly seen that for all cases and or all volume fractions of configurations with three cylinders the Case C has the most 𝑁𝑢 𝑖 values among all other models and it is followed e Case 2A and Case 2B, respectively. For all cases and for all volume ractions of configurations with four cylinders the Case 3B has the most 𝑢 𝑖 values among all other models and it is followed be Case 3C and
ase 3A, respectively.

metadata.abstractText: In the present numerical study, the free convective flow between several differentially hot and cold tubes enclosed in a space between two horizontal adiabatic coaxial cylinders which filled with three different kinds of nano-fluids is investigated. The effects of influential aspects including; location of heat source/sink, number of tubes, Rayleigh number ( Ra ), volume concentration ( φ) and type of the nanoadditives on the isotherms, streamline, stream function and average Nusselt number ( Nu i ) are explored. The governing equations are solved numerically employing control-volume based finite volume technique. For pressure-velocity coupling, the Semi-Implicit Method is utilized. According to the obtained results, usage of nano-fluid leads to the considerable enhancement of heat transfer in the studied cavity. For all the examined configurations with two cylinders, the configuration 30° has the most Nu i values which is followed by configurations 60° or 0°, 90°, 120°, 150° and 180°, respectively. It is clearly seen that for all the assessed configurations with three cylinders, the highest to lowest Nu i respectively belongs to the Case 2C, Case 2A and Case 2B. Moreover, for all the investigated configurations with four cylinders, the highest and lowest Nu i respectively occurs at Case 3B and Case 3A.
